comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/23885771@N03/] a single boiler would have to be much larger, and positioned above the carrying wheels would raise the centre of gravity considerably. Having two boilers means they could be smaller and lower, keeping the whole thing more stable.

The turntable/point arrangement is a fascinating piece of engineering and design.

comment.author: 64555638@N00
comment._content: More info in the Lartigue monorail here. [http://www.flickr.com/photos/23885771@N03] According to that Wikipedia piece there were two fireboxes, one of which had to be stoked by the driver. The locomotives were of the 0-6-0 type (strictly speaking, 0-3-0), constructed by the Hunslet Engine Company. They were specially built with two boilers in order to balance on the track, and consequently two fireboxes, one of which had to be stoked by the driver. They were also fitted with powered tenders for auxiliary use on hills. The tender wheels were driven by two cylinders via spur gears. Two small chimneys were fitted to each tender to discharge the exhaust steam from these cylinders.

comment._content: When I was an apprentice at Hunslet Engine Co in the early 1970's, I remember spending time looking through old drawings held in a basement in the company and coming across the original drawings for these locos. They were drawn in ink on linen and were absolute works of art and they were over 80 years old then. The current railway can be seen at Lartigue Monorail
